SENT.plain: Progesterone (PROG) is a neurosteroid, possessing a variety of functions in the central nervous system
Exogenous PROG has been shown to reduce secondary neuronal loss in conjunction with attenuated brain edema after cerebral contusion and to reduce brain edema after focal cerebral ischemia
In the present study, we assessed the neuroprotective potential of PROG in a model of focal cerebral ischemia in the rat

Forty-eight male Wistar rats were randomly assigned to 4 groups, i.e. pretreatment with water soluble PROG, or dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) dissolved PROG, or DMSO as control or delayed treatment with DMSO dissolved PROG
Middle cerebral artery occlusion (MCAO) was induced by insertion of an intraluminal suture and reperfusion was performed by withdrawing the suture
Pretreatments were initiated 30 min before MCAO via intraperitoneal injection
Delayed treatment was initiated upon reperfusion following 2 h of MCAO
Infarct volume, body weight loss, and neurological deficit were measured 48 h after MCAO

Pre- and delayed treatment with DMSO dissolved PROG resulted in a 39% (P < 0.05) and 34% (P < 0.05) reduction in cerebral infarction, respectively, along with decreased body weight loss and improved neurological function as compared to control animals, whereas no statistically significant reduction in infarct volume by water soluble PROG was found
We demonstrated that administration of PROG to the male rat before or 2 hours after onset of MCAO reduces ischemic cell damage and improves physiological and neurological function 2 days after stroke
These results suggests potential therapeutic properties of PROG in the management of stroke
